candidate_text: Section 174 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) was amended by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) in 2017.
Section 174 of the Internal Revenue Code deals with research and experimental expenditures, and the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) introduced significant changes to this provision.
A specific tax question!
A tax-related question!
A very specific question!
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) of 2017 made several changes to the US tax code, including an amendment to Section 174.
Section 174 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) deals with research and experimental expenditures, which can be expensed or capitalized by taxpayers.
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA), also known as the Tax Reform Act of 2017, introduced an amendment to Section 174, specifically Section 174(a).
Prior to the TCJA, Section 174 allowed taxpayers to elect to deduct research and experimentation expenses in the year incurred, rather than capitalizing them over time.
Prior to the TCJA, taxpayers could deduct Research and Development (R&D) expenses in the year incurred under Section 174(a).
Prior to TCJA, taxpayers could deduct research and experimental expenses in the year they were incurred under Section 174(a).

Prior to TCJA, taxpayers could elect to expense qualified research expenses in the year they were incurred, rather than capitalizing them over their useful life.
Prior to TCJA, Section 174 allowed businesses to immediately deduct their research and experimental expenditures (R&E expenses) in the year incurred, rather than capitalizing them over time.
Prior to the TCJA, research and experimental expenditures could be either deducted currently under Section 174(a) or amortized over a period not exceeding 60 months under Section 174(b).
Prior to the TCJA, taxpayers could elect to deduct research and experimental expenditures (R&E expenses) in the year they were incurred, rather than capitalizing them over time.

Prior to TCJA, taxpayers could elect to deduct research and experimental expenditures (R&E expenses) in the year they were incurred, rather than capitalizing them over time.

Here's what it does:

**Amendment to Section 174(a)**: As part of the TCJA, Congress modified Section 174(a) to repeal the option to immediately expense research and experimental (R&E) expenditures for tax years beginning after December 31, 2021.
Prior to the TCJA, taxpayers could elect to expense research and experimentation expenses under Section 174(a).

Prior to the TCJA, research and experimental expenditures were allowed as a current deduction under Section 174(a).

Prior to TCJA, research and development (R&D) expenses under Section 174 could be expensed in full in the year incurred, unless the taxpayer elected to amortize them over a period not exceeding 60 months.

According to this amendment, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2021:

**Specified research expenses must now be capitalized and amortized over a period of time**, rather than being fully deductible in the year they're incurred.
